Title.evidence: This randomised controlled trial investigated the comparative performance of predictors of fluid responsiveness in children

Trial_Design.evidence: participants were randomised to shock or non-shock states

Participants.evidence: The trial included children under 18 years, assessing physiological responses to intravenous fluid administration. Conducted in both PICU and non-PICU settings

Intervention.evidence: participants were randomised to shock or non-shock states

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial investigated the comparative performance of predictors of fluid responsiveness in children

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) for fluid responsiveness, evaluated over a defined period

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors

Result_Outcome.evidence: Meta-analysis indicated poor predictive performance across all tools (AUROC 0.66, 95% CI [0.63, 0.69])

Harms.evidence: no significant adverse events were reported
